item.title: My First Try
item.dc:creator: @Nashi Nashi
item.description:
@Nashi wrote:

You missed a / up the top next to the imports

You put 90 instead of having shift down and typing () in the init method

You put a space between “first” & “number” and between “second” & “number”
When you were trying to get to the variables firstnumber and secondnumber

You had a . instead of a , in the drawString part.

You didn’t import java.applet,
It’s JOptionPane not JOption

You spelt drawRect with the wrong casing

[code]//Fig. 3.13: AdditionApplet.java
//Adding two floating-point numbers.

//Java packages
import java.awt.Graphics; //import class graphics
import javax.swing.JOptionPane; //JOptionPane
import java.applet.*; //import java applet

public class AdditionApplet extends Applet {
double sum; //sum of values entered by users

//intalize applet by obtaining values from user
public void init()
{
   String firstnumber;  //first string entered by user
   String secondnumber; //second string entered by user

   double number1;      //first number to add
   double number2;      //second number to add

   //obtain first number from user
   firstnumber = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(
      "Enter fist floating point value" );

   //obtain second number from user
   secondnumber = JOptionPane.showInputDialog(
      "Enter second floating point value" );

   //convert numbers from String to type double
   number1 = Double.parseDouble( firstnumber );
   number2 = Double.parseDouble( secondnumber );

   //add numbers
   sum = number1 + number2;

} //end method limit

//draw results in a rectangle on applets backround
public void paint( Graphics g )
{
//call auperclass version of method paint
super.paint( g );
//draw rectangle starting from (15, 10) that is 270
//pixels wide andd 20 pixels tall
g.drawRect( 15, 10, 270, 20 );

   //draw results as a String at(25, 25)
   g.drawString( "The sum is " + sum, 25, 25 );

}//end method paint

}//end class AdditionApplet[/code]

Woah everyones complementing him and I pointed out whats wrong >_<

It’s good though D:

Read full topic

item.title: My First Try
item.dc:creator: @swordskid61 Swordskid61
item.description:
@swordskid61 wrote:

[code]//Fig. 3.13: AdditionApplet.java
//Adding two floating-point numbers.

//Java packages
import java.awt.Graphics; //import class graphics
import javax.swing.*; /import javax swing

public class AdditionApplet extends Japplet {
double sum; //sum of values entered by users

//intalize applet by obtaining values from user
public void init90
{
   String firstnumber;  //first string entered by user
   String secondnumber; //second string entered by user
   
   double number1;      //first number to add
   double number2;      //second number to add

   //obtain first number from user
   firstnumber = JOption.showInputDialog(
      "Enter fist floating point value" );

   //obtain second number from user
   secondnumber = JOption.showInputDialog(
      "Enter second floating point value" );

   //convert numbers from String to type double
   number1 = Double.parseDouble( first number );
   number2 = Double.parseDouble( second number );

   //add numbers
   sum = number1 + number2;

} //end method limit

//draw results in a rectangle on applets backround
public void paint( Graphics g )
{
//call auperclass version of method paint
super.paint( g );
//draw rectangle starting from (15, 10) that is 270
//pixels wide andd 20 pixels tall
g.Drawrect( 15, 10, 270, 20 );

   //draw results as a String at(25, 25)
   g.drawString( "The sum is " + sum. 25, 25 );

}//end method paint

}//end class AdditionApplet
[/code]
i know i probably murdered it but, it’s my first try at it.
